intro: Senecio morrumbalaensis, commonly known as the Morrumbala groundsel, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude grasslands of Mozambique. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters, with slender, erect stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer, producing yellowish to orange-colored inflorescences that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its restricted habitat, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in its native region.
